title: What causes insomnia? - Dan Kwartler

multiple-choice.question: What is the world's most common sleep disorder?
What can cause the occasional restless night?

options.label: A
options.text: Snoring partner, physical pain, or emotional distress

multiple-choice.question: What can throw off a person's biological clock and wreak havoc on their sleep schedule?
What is a long-term stress that can overpower fatigue?

options.label: B
options.text: Respiratory disorders, gastrointestinal problems, and many others

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary source of energy for the brain?
What happens to the metabolism of insomniacs while they sleep?

options.label: A
options.text: A long-term condition where a person sleeps soundly every night

options.label: B
options.text: A long-term condition where a person experiences cycles of stress and restlessness that last several months

options.label: C
options.text: A short-term condition where a person experiences occasional restless nights

options.label: D
options.text: A condition where a person sleeps too much

multiple-choice.question: What increases the risk of experiencing depression and anxiety?

options.label: C
options.text: Suffering from any one of these conditions

multiple-choice.question: What is a treatment for insomnia that involves managing stress and hyperarousal?

options.label: D
options.text: Relaxing activities like reading, meditating, or journaling

multiple-choice.question: What is a condition that can cause difficulty falling asleep at a typical bedtime, but is not due to increased stress?

title: You can grow new brain cells. Here's how - Sandrine Thuret

multiple-choice.question: Can adults grow new nerve cells?

options.label: A
options.text: No, adults do not grow new nerve cells.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, adults can grow new nerve cells, but only in certain parts of the brain.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, adults can grow new nerve cells in any part of the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: It's still unclear if adults can grow new nerve cells.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the brain structure where new neurons can be generated in adults?

What is the effect of stress on neurogenesis?

options.label: B
options.text: Stress has no effect on neurogenesis.

options.label: D
options.text: Stress increases neurogenesis in certain parts of the brain.

multiple-choice.question: What type of diet is beneficial for neurogenesis?
What is the effect of running on neurogenesis?

options.label: B
options.text: Running has no effect on neurogenesis.

options.label: D
options.text: Running decreases neurogenesis in certain parts of the brain.

multiple-choice.question: What type of exercise is beneficial for neurogenesis?
What is the effect of flavonoids on neurogenesis?

options.label: B
options.text: Flavonoids have no effect on neurogenesis.

options.label: D
options.text: Flavonoids decrease neurogenesis in certain parts of the brain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of omega-3 fatty acids on neurogenesis?

options.label: B
options.text: Omega-3 fatty acids have no effect on neurogenesis.

options.label: D
options.text: Omega-3 fatty acids decrease neurogenesis in certain parts of the brain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of resveratrol on neurogenesis?

options.label: B
options.text: Resveratrol has no effect on neurogenesis.

options.label: D
options.text: Resveratrol decreases neurogenesis in certain parts of the brain.

title: Lessons from the longest study on human development - Helen Pearson

multiple-choice.question: How many children were involved in the British birth cohorts study across five generations?

options.label: B
options.text: Parents really matter, especially in the first few years of life.

options.label: C
options.text: Poverty doesn't matter if a child is born poor.

options.label: D
options.text: Talking to children and reading to them every day is the only thing that matters.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the most surprising findings from the British study?

options.label: A
options.text: Children who had a tough start in life are more likely to end up unhealthy as adults.

options.label: B
options.text: Children who had engaged, interested parents were more likely to escape a difficult start.

options.label: C
options.text: Children who were born into poverty are more likely to do worse at school.

options.label: D
options.text: Children who had a tough start in life are more likely to end up wealthy as adults.

options.label: A
options.text: It showed that children who went to bed at different times were more likely to have behavioral problems.

options.label: B
options.text: It showed that children who went to bed at regular times were more likely to have behavioral problems.

options.label: C
options.text: It showed that bedtime routines had no effect on children's behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: It showed that bedtime routines were not important for children's development.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main conclusion of the study on the relationship between poverty and parenting?

options.label: A
options.text: Poverty doesn't matter if a child is born poor.

options.label: B
options.text: Good parenting can overcome the effects of poverty.

options.label: C
options.text: Poverty leaves a lasting scar, and tackling child poverty is an important thing to do.

options.label: D
options.text: Poverty has no effect on children's development.

multiple-choice.question: What did the author do after learning about the British study?

options.label: A
options.text: They started working more hours and ignoring their children.

options.label: B
options.text: They introduced talking time with their children.

options.label: C
options.text: They stopped reading to their children.

options.label: D
options.text: They didn't change their parenting style at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main takeaway from the study for parents?

options.label: A
options.text: That they should talk to their children and read to them every day.

options.label: B
options.text: That they should put their children to bed on time and give them a book to read.

options.label: C
options.text: That they should do whatever they want and ignore the science.

options.label: D
options.text: That they should not worry about their children's development.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the limitations of the study?

options.label: A
options.text: It only looked at a small number of children.

options.label: B
options.text: It only looked at children from wealthy families.

options.label: C
options.text: It looks at what happens to thousands and thousands of children on average, but that doesn't necessarily say what will help my child or your child.

options.label: D
options.text: It looked at children from all over the world.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message from the study on the importance of parenting?

options.label: A
options.text: That parents are not important for their children's development.

options.label: B
options.text: That parents really matter, especially in the first few years of life.

options.label: C
options.text: That parents have no effect on their children's behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: That parents are only important if they are wealthy.

multiple-choice.question: What did the author say was the main lesson they learned from the study?

options.label: A
options.text: That they should choose their parents very carefully.

options.label: B
options.text: That they should talk to their children and read to them every day.

options.label: C
options.text: That they should put their children to bed on time and give them a book to read.

options.label: D
options.text: That they should listen to the science and their children themselves.

title: Honey: bacteria's worst enemy

multiple-choice.question: What is honey, according to the video?

options.label: A
options.text: A supersaturated solution of water and sugar.

options.label: B
options.text: A liquidy sugar in a plastic bear bottle.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main trick of honey for fighting bacteria?
What is glucose oxidase, and what does it do?

options.label: A
options.text: It's an enzyme that produces hydrogen peroxide and gluconic acid, which kill bacteria.

options.label: B
options.text: It's an enzyme that breaks down glucose into fructose.

options.label: C
options.text: It's an enzyme that produces water and oxygen.

options.label: D
options.text: It's an enzyme that has no effect on bacteria.

options.text: It's a protein that defends bees from certain bacteria.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a protein that kills bacteria in honey.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a protein that has no effect on bacteria.

multiple-choice.question: What is methylglyoxal, and where is it found?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a small organic molecule that forms in honey from a compound in the nectar of certain flowers.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a type of bacteria that causes botulism.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a protein that defends bees from certain bacteria.

multiple-choice.question: What is botulinum toxin, and how is it produced?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a toxin that is produced by the bacteria that causes botulism.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a toxin that is produced by the spores of the bacteria that causes botulism.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a toxin that is produced by the nectar of certain flowers.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a toxin that has no effect on humans.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it not safe to give honey to infants under one year old?

options.label: C
options.text: Because the spores of the bacteria that causes botulism can germinate and start producing toxin.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between manuka honey and other types of honey?

options.label: A
options.text: Manuka honey is made from a type of flower that is found only in New Zealand.

options.label: B
options.text: Manuka honey has a higher concentration of methylglyoxal than other types of honey.

options.label: C
options.text: Manuka honey is made from a type of bee that is found only in New Zealand.

options.label: D
options.text: Manuka honey has no special properties.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of glucose oxidase in honey?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce hydrogen peroxide and gluconic acid, which kill bacteria.

options.label: B
options.text: To break down glucose into fructose.

options.label: C
options.text: To have no effect on bacteria.

multiple-choice.question: Why is honey a good antibacterial agent?

options.label: C
options.text: Because it has a combination of water-sucking properties, acidity, and antibiotic compounds that make it effective against bacteria.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it has no effect on bacteria.

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

What is the name of the area in the nasal septum where four different arteries come together to form a network of blood vessels?

What is the recommended way to stop a nosebleed?

options.label: A
options.text: Pinch the soft part of the nose for 10 minutes

multiple-choice.question: What can a doctor use to cauterize a broken blood vessel in the nose?
What should you do to prevent nosebleeds?

options.label: A
options.text: Keep your fingers away from your nostrils

multiple-choice.question: What should you do if you get a nosebleed?

options.label: B
options.text: Pinch the soft part of your nose

title: Why tech needs the humanities

options.label: A
options.text: Jeff was unable to solve the problem, and the speaker's company was fired.

options.label: B
options.text: Jeff was able to disarmed the client's fixation on the programming skill and change the conversation.

options.label: C
options.text: Jeff was able to write the code to solve the problem, but the client was still unhappy.

options.label: D
options.text: Jeff was unable to figure out how to program the solution, and the client became a lost reference.

title: Why do I have to use a number 2 pencil?

options.text: It's highly conductive, allowing electricity to pass through it.

options.label: C
options.text: It's highly absorbent, making it easy to erase.

options.label: D
options.text: It's highly brittle, making it prone to breaking.

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with inventing the first mark-sensing machine for grading exams?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To create a light, temporary mark that can be easily erased.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a mark that is just dark enough to be sensed by the machine, but also light enough to be erased.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a mark that is only visible under specific lighting conditions.

options.label: D
options.text: It's highly brittle, making it prone to breaking.

options.label: C

options.text: To create a mark that is just dark enough to be sensed by the machine, but also light enough to be erased.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: To create a mark that is only visible under specific lighting conditions.

title: Why are we ticklish?

multiple-choice.question: What is the word that is an umbrella term for two different phenomena of tickling?

options.label: B

options.label: B
options.text: The equivalent of birds building nests

options.text: So people would learn how to tickle each other

options.label: C
options.text: So people would learn how to laugh

options.label: D
options.text: So people would learn how to smile

title: How old are your ears? (hearing test)

multiple-choice.question: What happens to our hearing spectrum as we grow older?

options.label: A
options.text: We lose the ability to hear low frequencies.

options.label: B
options.text: We lose the ability to hear high frequencies.

options.label: C
options.text: We lose the ability to hear both low and high frequencies.

options.label: D
options.text: We gain the ability to hear more frequencies.

multiple-choice.question: How many nerve cells are in the human ear responsible for picking up different frequencies?
What is the primary cause of hearing loss in older adults?

options.label: B
options.text: Continual exposure to noise and loud sounds

multiple-choice.question: What type of cells in the ear are responsible for picking up different frequencies and sending the signal to the brain?
Why do high frequencies go first in hearing loss?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are the loudest sounds.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are the most common sounds.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the hairs tuned to high pitches experience more stress and tend to degenerate earlier.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are the most important sounds.

multiple-choice.question: What is the age at which a person's hearing is likely to be at its best?
Can the inner ear regenerate?

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on the type of hearing loss

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which the inner ear loses its ability to hear high frequencies?
What type of sounds are most likely to cause hearing loss?
Why is it important to protect our hearing?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a sense that we use every day.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a sense that we can easily lose.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a sense that is essential for our overall health and well-being.

title: What if you never forgot anything?

options.label: A
options.text: We will have room for the things that matter.

options.label: B
options.text: We will forget the things that matter.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they can clearly remember every choice they made and how it turned out.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between memorization and truly understanding a concept?

options.label: D
options.text: Memorization requires more effort than understanding.

title: How to tame your wandering mind

options.label: B
options.text: To notice, select, and direct the brain's computational resources

options.label: A
options.text: A concept that refers to paying attention to the present moment

options.label: B
options.text: A practice that refers to ignoring distractions

options.label: C
options.text: A technique that refers to predicting future events

options.label: D
options.text: A skill that refers to remembering past events

options.label: C
options.text: It improves physical health and reduces mental health

options.label: D

title: When will the next ice age happen? - Lorraine Lisiecki

multiple-choice.question: What is the informal term commonly used to describe the period of time when huge ice sheets encased parts of North America, Asia, and Europe?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: They increase the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere

options.label: A
options.text: Changes in Earth's orbit around the sun

options.label: C
options.text: Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere
